prompt:
Is the person who wrote this in the wrong in the following situation?

"""
AITA For refusing to buy any of my family members a christmas gift?
Now, based off of the title, you probably already think “Damn, this kid’s an asshole.” But here’s some context.

The week before Christmas, I received a $400 target gift card I won in a drawing.  I bragged about it on Instagram, where my sister follows me on, and of course, she saw it. She gave me a phone call and asked me who gave it to me, and I explain the situation, and tell her specifically NOT TO TELL MOM, as I knew it was bad enough that my sister knew already. She hangs up, and a few minutes later, my mother comes bursting into my room. She asks to see the gift card, and I hand it to her. She gives it back, then she says, obnoxiously, “You have to get something for me and (Sister’s name), That frustrated me enough, but I agreed, (I am VERY conservative, especially with my money.) 

Then when I was at target, getting my stuff plus what I WAS gonna get for my mom and sister, I get a phone call from my mom. 

Mom: “Oh, also, you have to get something for (Cousin 1’s name) and (Cousin 2’s name,) as well. Be thoughtful, don’t just get something cheap.” She said, even more obnoxiously 

(We were visiting my Uncle and Aunt for christmas, and my cousins are 6 and 2, so why the hell would I need to spend that much money on two more people I don’t and won’t see often?)

Me: “No thanks.” I then hung up the phone and ignored the rest of my mom’s texts and phone calls.

I spoiled myself, changing my mind about getting anyone else anything, because of how obnoxious everyone was being towards me after finding out what I had, so I spoiled myself. Bought myself a pair of airpods, GTA V, PlayStation Plus,a cheap laptop to do work on, and some new wrestling gear. Also bought a buddy of mine a bluetooth speaker, and spent the rest on candy and whatnot. 

Walked home and my mother was expecting that I got everyone a gift. Boy, was she shocked (despite our last phone call.) I got an ass chewing and she tried to guilt trip me, (unsuccessfully.) 

We were arguing then I just said “Maybe if you weren’t being so greedy about the situation, and kept your paws off of my money, I wouldn’t have changed my mind about getting you guys something!” (My exact words with some stuttering in it,) 

She then yelled at me a final time, marched to her room, and slammed her door. 

Typing that first paragraph made my blood boil, and reminded me of why I’m gonna keep all future assets private to me and me only. 

I’m 15 years old, if that will affect your criticism at all. 





"""

Is the author in the wrong? Answer A for Yes (the author is in the wrong) and B for No (the author is not in the wrong). Answer nothing else.

thinking.text:
Okay, let's break this down. The user is asking whether the 15-year-old is in the wrong for refusing to buy Christmas gifts for family members after someone else found out about a gift card.

First, the kid got a $400 Target gift card and shared it on Instagram. His sister saw it and told their mom, which he didn't want. Then, when he went to buy gifts, his mom kept adding more people he had to get gifts for. He decided not to buy any gifts for them because of how pushy they were. 

He used the money for himself and a friend. His mom was upset and felt he should have bought gifts. The kid is defending himself by saying they were being greedy and he wanted to keep his money. 

So, is he wrong? Well, family dynamics can be tricky. In many cultures, especially in Western ones, exchanging gifts during Christmas is a common tradition. However, the situation here is complicated by the pressure from his mom and the fact that she kept adding more people after their initial conversation. The kid is 15, which is a teenager, and they might not have a lot of money. The mom might expect that if he has the means, he should contribute to family traditions. 

On the other hand, the mom did call him out after the fact, which led to an argument. The kid feels that his mom and sister were inconsiderate by not respecting his wishes after he had already decided to use the money. The key points here are the pressure from the family and the kid's right to manage his own money. 

Is it fair for the family to expect gifts? It depends on family norms. If the family usually exchanges gifts and the kid is able to contribute, then maybe there's an expectation. But if the family is adding people without considering the kid's financial situation or his initial reluctance, that's where the issue lies. 

The kid did mention he's very conservative with money, so maybe he's not in a position to spend $400 on multiple family members, especially for cousins he doesn't see often. Also, the mom's initial reaction of being obnoxious and then the guilt-tripping might not be helpful. 

In terms of cultural expectations, some might say it's a tradition to give gifts, but others might argue that it's his money to spend as he chooses. Since he's a minor, there might be a parental expectation to some extent, but the pushy behavior could have backfired. 

Considering all that, the answer might be a mix of both. But the question is whether the author is in the wrong. If the family pressures him beyond reasonable expectations and he's using his own money, then maybe he's justified. However, in some contexts, refusing to participate in a family tradition could be seen as inconsiderate. 

But given the circumstances, the mom and sister's pressure, and the fact that he's a teenager with limited resources, the answer might lean towards the author not being in the wrong. So, answer B.
